text:
The book "Pioneers" was completed in 1906.

Dear Mr. Johnson,

I have been very busy preparing for the Pioneer's Day celebration. I will be there after the Pioneer's Day celebration.

Yours sincerely,
[Signature]

P.S. They were here earlier today.
The late Mr. James Brown

From Jan. 5th, 1906

Dear Mr. James Brown,

I have been very busy preparing for the coming year. I have been working hard to get everything ready for the new season.

I hope you will be able to make it through this year without any problems. Please let me know how things are going.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

January 5th, 1906
There were four children here after
my parents died. Here again
were I studied at West Virginia
State College and several
of my companions became
friends. Anything
for of their pleasure
I can recall was ever
pleasant. Remember
Miss Maudie - Kelli
Remember Miss Maudie Til Further Notice
There were times there often
were times there often
were times there often
were times there often
were times there often

I attended North Central College
for years. The college offered
a variety of classes, including
anything from business courses
to art classes.

Remember always to smile,
remember always to smile,
remember always to smile,
remember always to smile,
remember always to smile,

I never heard anyone say,
"I never heard anyone say,
"I never heard anyone say,
"I never heard anyone say,
"I never heard anyone say,

The memories are still fresh,
the memories are still fresh,
the memories are still fresh,
the memories are still fresh,
the memories are still fresh,
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Tobias G. Lamegaff
Address: Meadow Lake
Birthplace: Swift Current, Minn., U.S.A.

INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? May 10, 1906.
Where did you set up housekeeping? 3½ miles south of Waynecroft.
Where had you been living before that? Swift Current, Minn., U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4.
How far was it to your nearest store? 3½ miles to Battleford.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? We bought tea, coffee, sugar, yeast flour, hard rice, oatmeal, tobacco for pipe, matches, writing paper, envelopes, salt, oil, pork.
We had a tiny garden in 1907 or we used syrup. Bought flour from the Bishop Mill or Lamegaff Bros.

FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? We used syrup.
In what quantities did you buy it? 1 lb.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.90 in 1911; I know $4.50 a ton.
How much did you use graham flour? For hot cakes.
Whole wheat flour? For hot cakes.
Was flour milled locally? No.
How far away? In what part?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00.
What other grain products did you use? We had milk, butter, and rolled rice.
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, I had a hand chopper.
How did you grind it? Boiled wheat whole is good to eat in the morning also. One poor family ground wheat and made bread with it. He used 2 feed drive choppers. He turned one crank. This was the other. These choppers crushed the grain like rolled oats.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? About 20 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? Approximately $1.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We kept cows and milked them twice a day.

Did you make butter, eggs, cheese? Yes.

What was the price of butter? Not sure.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter, eggs, cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Butter, cheddar.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We had ducks, chickens, sparrows, antelope.

How did you get fresh meat? We had ducks, etc., and used antelope.

How often did you get fresh meat? We carried a shot gun or rifle all the time.

How did you preserve meat? We kept them dry by hanging them.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized? Not sure.

Did you use game? Yes, we had turkeys.

What kinds? Quail, chickens, sometimes we ate badger.

For how long? Not sure, we got them from the river.

What part did fish play in the family diet? We got fish at Jackfish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh in summer, Rogers in winter.

Kinds? White fish, blue gills.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon
At what price? 75¢ per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)
Price? 5¢ per lb.

What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 2.5¢

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1907 Cabbage 1907 Carrots 1907 Onions 1907
Turnips 1907 Beets 1907

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? about 10 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk but

What weight? 10 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes

What was the price of prunes? about 10¢

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

1907 we worked for Major in

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes

peas? corn? beans? Saskatoons? yes

other foods? There were some wild berries

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1945

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1945

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1945

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? drying only

To what extent? Not much

Did you make your own vinegar? No

I am retired now 75 years old over.

I am living with my son Tommy
nearby 2½ mi. N.E. of Meadow Lake.

I am too old to hunt-trap & fish.
& teach Sunday School to Indian children on the Reserve for a small remuneration of $1.00 per month.
6. **BEVERAGES**
   - What kind of tea did you buy? (Price per pound)
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (Price per pound)
   - What kind of soft drinks did you buy? (Price per bottle)

7. **VEGETABLES AND FRUITS**
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
   - Could you get potatoes at the store?
   - That year did you first grow your own supply for the winter?
   - In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?
   - How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box)?
   - What was the price of prunes?

8. **PREPARING FOOD**
   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by canning?
   - What year did you first preserve fruit by canning?
   - What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

9. **OTHER**
   - Did you make your own vinegar?
   - What kind of flour did you buy?
   - What kind of sugar did you buy?
   - What kind of salt did you buy?
   - What kind of tea did you buy?
   - What kind of coffee did you buy?
   - What kind of soft drinks did you buy?

10. **CHILDREN**
    - Teach Sunday School to children on the premises for a dollar per quarter.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Cakes
Did you make yeast for your own use? No
Using starter? Yes
Using hops? No
Salt rising? No
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? No
Did you make your own baking powder? No

Did you make yeast for your own use?

Cream of tartar?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) | Well 400 feet east of house - 12 ft deep |
How far was this water from your home? | 400 yards |
How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) | Pail, barrel |
Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

1909 I moved north 70 mi (for stock). There was a deep ravine we dug a shallow well got lot of good water. 1918 I moved up to Dominick's built near a lake lots good water there.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, stream)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Did you start a household supply where possible?

There was a deep well near the house.

1918 I moved up to Demuth's house.

near a well. Put good water there.
My mother & Father have died
1908 & 1910 eldest sister & brother 5 & 3
Married 1924 had one son
This woman got sick went home
I stayed alone 6-12 years
Then I joined an Indian Family 1795
13. Soaps
We worked co-operative
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?
If you made your own, did you use wood ashes?
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. Fuel
What fuel did you use in the earliest days?
Where did you get your fuel?
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

1909 I moved north 70 miles
To see 10 49 16 W 3
10 Mi N.E. of Jackfish Lake South
There was wood that time free
1918 I came up here to Deseronto
Settled near waterhen Lake there was lots of dry wood thousands of acres.

15. Methods of Cooking and Types of Utensils
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)
By whom was your first cook stove made? Sears & Roebuck, USA
What year was it purchased? 1894 Price? $56.50
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)
When did you first see enamel ware?
Aluminum?
Dear Mr. Laneagraff,

I am writing to you in the hope that you may be able to assist me in my research. I am currently working on a project that involves the study of early American households and their cooking methods.

I have been gathering information from various sources, including family records and oral histories. However, I am still missing some crucial details that would help me complete my research.

Could you please provide any information you may have regarding the types of utensils used in early American households? Specifically, I am interested in knowing what materials were commonly used for cooking pots and pans.

Additionally, I would appreciate any insights you may have on the types of fuels used during that time period. Were there any innovations or changes in fuel use that you can share?

Thank you very much for your assistance. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
3) I earn $100 per month for teaching Sunday School. I am in full charge of the work here for the Sunday School by mail correspondence from Winnipeg, Man.

I serve the Indians children in Green Lake, Meadow Lake, Loon Lake & Waterhen Lake. Mostly Indian children.

I have lived a long time near Waterhen Lake Reserve and seen 5 generations grow up from our family tree. The older ones died and new ones spring up.

The first family tree I knew was Osayun or Torchwood & his wife both deceased.

2nd was Pasaguns & daughters.

Opepon now at Loon Lake Sask.

3rd Little Cheebisk died about 1924.

Kipish now at Long Lake Res. Alta.

Opepon had 1 son Mistake named.

3rd Osayun Opusines Opepons daughter.

Osayun Opusines had 3 sons 1 daughter.

Harry Blackbird 29 yrs old lives at Loon Lake & Waterhen Sask.

4th Stanley Opepon 17 deceased 1953.

Lewis Opusines 16 alive at Loon Lake & Waterhen Sask.

Rosa her daughter died 1948.

Harry was married & got one.

5th Victor is Harry's son 5 yrs old. He lives with Edward Abraham.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

1945: Paper cartons for 12 eggs.

1944: They don't use wrapping and only paper stickers with glue on.

1943: We got wooden boxes for groceries, new paper boxes.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1906: Breakfast - Oatmeal, hot cakes or toast, bread, butter, potatoes fried, tomatoes, tea, nuts, coffee, cream, salt, sugar, pepper. We often made brown gravy.

1906: Dinner - Vegetables, beans with dumplings, 3 wild ducks cut up, baked, bread, butter, cream, tea, coffee.

Supper - Fries, eggs, potatoes fried, boiled first.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1907: We went back to U.S., fall 1906.

Back to Sask., early 1907.

Thomas, that was dad, 70 yrs old.
O.T. brother, 33 yrs old, wife & 7 children.
P.E. brother, 21.
T.G. myself, 18 yrs old, in 1907, during the same good dinner.

We had a fair Christmas dinner.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I was living on barrel & rabbits. I got so tired of rabbits I hated to look them in the face. 1953, 1954, 1955 we have only a few rabbits left. They have been killed by predator animals.

People don't trap long fur animals like lynx, coyote, etc. There is no sale for that kind of fur. Mink are in demand & beaver musk.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappingage and containers received.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give also the number and ages of the family members present at breakfast time. State the approximate month, e.g., when or near what season.

18. What year did you have your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give details.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two pounds of flour per week? Give details.

61. What wild animals were used for religion?
I don't follow the thread.

Alice Miller came to visit. She brought potatoes, apples, and carrots. We cooked them in the oven and ate them with butter and sugar.

We also had a fish dinner. I caught a trout from the creek and cooked it over an open fire.

We had a great time at Beaver Creek. We went for a swim and played in the water.

It was too hot to work on the farm. We went to the creek instead.

We planted corn and beans. We also had a garden of tomatoes and cucumbers.

We harvested our crops in September and stored them for winter.

After harvest, we moved to the city. Alice Miller joined us there.

We lived in the city until 1918 when we moved back to the farm.
Oxford

No. 613 S
